Based on the options provided, the correct combination of drugs used for cyanide poisoning is: 1, 2, and 3

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: C. 1, 2, and 3

questions.text: The leading cause of bladder outlet obstruction in male children is: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Posterior urethral valve

 

This is the most common cause of lower urinary tract obstruction in male infants. PUV is a congenital malformation found only in boys where there is an abnormal fold of tissue in the posterior urethra, preventing normal urine outflow and leading to bladder outlet obstruction. The condition can lead to hydronephrosis if not treated promptly.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Urethral atresia: This is a rare congenital anomaly where a segment of the urethra fails to canalize or develop. It leads to complete obstruction of the urethra, and while it does cause bladder outlet obstruction, it is less common than PUV in male children.

 

Option C. Anterior urethral valve: This is a rare congenital anomaly and is much less common than the posterior urethral valve. While it can cause obstruction, its prevalence and significance in causing bladder outlet obstruction in male children are far less than that of PUV.

 

Option D. Ureterocele: A ureterocele is a cystic dilation of the terminal ureter within the bladder. It can cause obstruction of the ureter itself. They are not the leading cause in male children when compared to PUV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The most frequent cause of bladder outflow obstruction in male children is the posterior urethral valve (PUV).
  • PUV is a membranous fold located in the posterior urethra, typically found just distal to the verumontanum. It is thought to occur due to the persistence of the urogenital membrane.
  • Urethral obstruction can cause dilation of the posterior urethral valve, bladder, and bilateral hydronephrosis, leading to a keyhole sign on prenatal ultrasound and potentially oligohydramnios.
  • If not detected prenatally, PUV may present postnatally as a newborn or young infant with urinary tract symptoms, abdominal distension or and recurrent UTIs.
  • Left untreated, PUV may result in chronic kidney disease, bladder dysfunction, and vesicoureteral reflux.
  • Diagnosis of PUV is typically based on the presence of an elongated posterior valve during the voiding phase of the voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG).

questions.text: Which of the following antimicrobials is effective against an organism producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Piperacillin - tazobactam

 

ESBL is produced by gram-negative organisms like Klebsiella and E. coli. They are resistant to most of the Beta-lactam antibiotics like Penicillin and most of the Cephalosporins. Tazobactam, Sulbactam and Clavulanic acid are beta lactamase inhibitors, hence they can be used against ESBL producing organisms. Therefore, the correct option will be Piperacillin+ Tazobactam combination.

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against ESBL-producing organisms because tazobactam inhibits the beta-lactamase enzyme, allowing piperacillin to exert its antibacterial effect.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amoxicillin - clavulanic acid: Although clavulanic acid is a beta-lactamase inhibitor, the combination of amoxicillin and clavulanic acid is generally less effective against ESBL-producing organisms compared to piperacillin-tazobactam.

 

Option B. Penicillin: Penicillin alone is not effective against ESBL-producing organisms because it is susceptible to degradation by beta-lactamases.

 

Option D. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone, a third-generation cephalosporin, is generally ineffective against ESBL-producing organisms as they can hydrolyze this class of antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Piperacillin-tazobactam is effective against organisms producing extended-spectrum beta-lactamases (ESBLs) due to the beta-lactamase inhibitory action of tazobactam, which protects piperacillin from enzymatic degradation, allowing it to kill the bacteria.

choices.text: No dose adjustment is required
Add tenofovir 150 mg in the morning
Add lamivudine 300 mg in the morning
Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

questions.text: A patient with history of HIV was started on anti-retroviral therapy consisting of lamivudine 300 mg, tenofovir 150 mg and dolutegravir 50 mg once daily at night. Few weeks later, he developed tuberculosis and was started on anti-tubercular drugs. Which of the following dose adjustment may be required in this patient? (Fmge Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Add dolutegravir 50 mg in the morning

 

Adjustment of ARV regimen with concomitant ATT:

 

  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + 1NNRTI (EFV)–based regimen has to be given 2HRZE + 4HRE–based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued without any modification.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + DTG–based regimen has to be given Rifampicin-based ATT for the newly detected TB, same ART regimen can be continued. However, since co-administered rifampicin reduces bioavailability of DTG, which can be overcome by an additional tablet of DTG 50 mg (at an interval of 12 hours with the regular dose of DTG) till the completion of ATT. Once the ATT is completed, additional tablet of DTG 50 mg should be stopped 2 weeks after stoppage of Rifampicin-containing treatment regimen.
  • When a patient already on 2NRTIs + PI–based regimen develops TB, ART regimen has to be modified if 2HREZ + 4HRE–based ATT is co-administered.
    • If the patient has not taken DTG earlier, patient is shifted to 2 NRTIs + DLG-based regimen with twice daily DTG as discussed in last section
    • If DLG cannot be given due to any reason and boosted PIs need to continued, then rifampicin should be replaced by rifabutin

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients on a dolutegravir-based regimen who start rifampicin-based anti-tubercular therapy, an additional dose of dolutegravir 50 mg should be taken in the morning (12 hours apart from the regular dose) to maintain effective drug levels and manage HIV effectively.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient has been diagnosed with bacterial vaginosis and trichomoniasis. She is prescribed metronidazole as part of her treatment plan. Which of the following should she avoid consuming while on this medication? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol

 

  • Patients taking metronidazole are advised to avoid alcohol consumption. Metronidazole and alcohol can interact to cause a disulfiram-like reaction, leading to symptoms such as flushing, nausea, vomiting, palpitations, and even more severe reactions in some cases. This interaction can occur not only with oral alcohol consumption but also with alcohol contained in mouthwashes and certain medications.
  • Disulfiram is an aversive drug, that inhibits the aldehyde dehydrogenase, leading to accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body, which can lead to symptoms like throbbing headache, flushing, chest tightness, visual disturbances, nausea etc. Hence these symptoms prevent the patient from taking alcohol.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: There is no known significant interaction between grapefruit juice and metronidazole.

 

Option C. Benzodiazepine: While caution may be advised when combining any medications that can have CNS effects, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between benzodiazepines and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Option D. SSRI: Similar to benzodiazepines, there is not a well-known, specific interaction between SSRIs and metronidazole that would warrant absolute avoidance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Drugs that can cause disulfiram like reaction include:

 

Cyclic:  Cefoperazone, Chlorpropamide

 

G:         Grieseofulvin

 

M:        Metronidazole

 

P:         Procarbazine

choices.text: Bradycardia with AV block
Torsades’ de pointes

questions.text: A patient was taking metoprolol for hypertension but blood pressure was not controlled. Verapamil was added to the regimen. Which of the following adverse effect is likely to be present with combination? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bradycardia with AV block
 

  • Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that is commonly used to hypertension, heart failure, and arrhythmias. It works by slowing down the heart rate and reducing the heart's demand for oxygen.
  • Verapamil, on the other hand, is a calcium channel blocker used for similar indications as metoprolol. It reduces the heart rate and has a negative inotropic effect (reduces the force of heart muscle contraction), and can affect the electrical conduction in the heart.
  • When used together, metoprolol and verapamil can have additive effects on the heart rate and atrioventricular (AV) nodal conduction. This can lead to:
    • Bradycardia: An abnormally slow heart rate.
    • AV block: A delay or complete block in the electrical impulse conduction through the AV node of the heart.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Torsades de pointes: This is a specific type of ventricular tachycardia that is not typically associated with the combination of metoprolol and verapamil. It is more often related to medications that prolong the QT interval.

 

Option C. Tachycardia: This is an increased heart rate, which is an unlikely side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil, as both tend to slow the heart rate.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: While this is a serious cardiac arrhythmia, it is not a typical side effect of combining metoprolol and verapamil. It's more commonly associated with ischemic heart disease or other structural heart problems.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of metoprolol and verapamil can lead to significant bradycardia and AV block due to their additive effects on slowing heart rate and AV nodal conduction.

questions.text: Which among the following drugs is the new FDA approved immune check point inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pembrolizumab

 

The new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium is Pembrolizumab.

 

Pembrolizumab is a monoclonal antibody against PD-1 receptor (Programmed Death Receptor) that can be used for many cancers including endometrial carcinoma. Some of the other cancers where it is useful are:

 

  • Metastatic urothelial cancer
  • Refractory melanoma
  • Hodgkin’s Lymphoma
  • Merkel cell cancer
  • Chemotherapy Refractory Head and Neck Cancer

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nivolumab: is an immune checkpoint inhibitor that acts by inhibiting programmed death receptor - 1 (PD-1) and is used for the treatment of advanced melanoma and relapsed/refractory classical Hodgkin lymphoma.

 

Option C. Trastuzumab: is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits the HER2 receptor. It is used in the treatment of HER2-positive breast cancer.

 

Option D. Ipilimumab: is a monoclonal antibody that binds to cytotoxic T lymphocyte-associated Protein 4 (CTLA-4) and is approved for the treatment of late-stage melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pembrolizumab is the new FDA-approved immune checkpoint inhibitor for carcinoma endometrium. It works by blocking the PD-1 receptor, enhancing the immune system's ability to attack cancer cells. It is also used for treating several other cancers, including metastatic urothelial cancer, refractory melanoma, Hodgkin’s lymphoma, Merkel cell cancer, and chemotherapy-refractory head and neck cancer.

questions.text: The loading dose of a drug is governed primarily by? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Volume of distribution

 

Loading dose = Volume of Distribution * Target plasma concentration.

 

Loading dose is the high initial dose of the drug that is initially given to cover the distribution so that the desired action can take place. In other words, when the time to reach a steady-state is long, it may be desirable to administer a loading dose that promptly raises the concentration of drug in plasma to the target concentration.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clearance: Clearance is a measure of the body's efficiency in eliminating the drug but does not determine the loading dose. It is more relevant to the maintenance dose.

 

Option C. Plasma half-life: The half-life of a drug determines how long it stays in the body but is not directly used to calculate the loading dose.

 

Option D. Bioavailability: Bioavailability refers to the fraction of the administered dose that reaches the systemic circulation. While important for understanding the effective dose, it does not govern the calculation of the loading dose.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The loading dose of a drug is primarily governed by its volume of distribution, which helps achieve the desired plasma concentration quickly, especially when the drug has a long half-life.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 154/94 mm Hg; Heart Rate 72 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 32 breaths/minute. He also complains of breathlessness. Which of the following is the preferred drug for management of this patient? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Prazosin


Scorpion venom causes release of a large amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals which can lead to hypertension, tachycardia, breathlessness due to pulmonary edema etc. These effects are counteracted by using Prazosin, which is a selective α1 blocker.

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Metoprolol: This is a beta-blocker used primarily for managing hypertension, heart rate control, and other cardiovascular conditions. It is not typically used in the management of scorpion stings, as it doesn't directly address the pathophysiological effects of the venom.

 

Option B. Ivabradine: This drug is used to reduce heart rate in certain conditions such as chronic heart failure and angina. It is not indicated for treating symptoms of scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Frusemide: This is a diuretic, primarily used to treat conditions like hypertension and edema. It does not have a direct role in managing the effects of a scorpion sting.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Prazosin is the preferred drug for managing the symptoms of a scorpion sting, as it counteracts the effects of catecholamines released due to the venom, providing relief from hypertension and pulmonary edema. Other drugs listed do not directly address the primary pathophysiological effects of a scorpion sting.
